[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Hash collision attack] Can an attacker craft malicious on-chain configurations that produce SHA3-256 hash collisions with legitimate environments, causing validators to incorrectly treat different execution contexts as equivalent and leading to consensus failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Hash preimage attack] If an attacker controls the order of data fed to sha3_256.update(), can they manipulate the hash computation to create environments with identical hashes but different actual configurations, bypassing deterministic execution guarantees? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: PartialEq::eq()] [Environment confusion] Since PartialEq only compares hash values, can an attacker exploit hash collisions to cause validators to accept incompatible environments as equivalent, leading to state divergence and chain splits? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: fetch_config_and_update_hash()] [Hash update ordering] Is the order of sha3_256.update() calls across different config types deterministic? Can reordering config fetches cause identical configurations to produce different hashes, breaking environment equality checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Partial hash inclusion] Are all security-critical fields included in the SHA3-256 hash? Can an attacker modify fields like async_runtime_checks_enabled or inject_create_signer_for_gov_sim without changing the hash, causing validators to use incompatible environments? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Hash timing attack] Can an attacker exploit timing differences in hash computation to infer sensitive configuration values or detect specific feature flags, enabling targeted attacks on validators? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Groth16 VK manipulation] Can an attacker submit a malicious Groth16 verification key through governance that passes keyless_account.move validation but causes proof verification to accept invalid keyless account signatures, enabling unauthorized fund access? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [VK parsing failure] When vk.try_into().ok() returns None due to malformed verification key, does the system safely reject all keyless transactions, or can an attacker exploit this to bypass keyless authentication entirely? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: keyless_pvk()] [Optional PVK exploit] Since keyless_pvk returns Option<PreparedVerifyingKey>, can an attacker force the VK to be None through on-chain manipulation, causing all keyless account operations to fail and permanently locking user funds? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [VK deserialization attack] Can an attacker craft verification key bytes that deserialize successfully but produce a PreparedVerifyingKey with corrupted elliptic curve points, causing proof verification to accept invalid proofs? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [VK hash bypass] Since the VK bytes are included in the environment hash, can an attacker submit a VK that produces the same hash as a legitimate VK but has different cryptographic properties, bypassing security checks? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Keyless config inconsistency] If keyless_pvk is Some but keyless_configuration is None (or vice versa), can this inconsistent state cause validators to process keyless transactions differently, leading to consensus divergence? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Gas parameter manipulation] When gas_params contains Err, the system uses zeros for NativeGasParameters and MiscGasParameters. [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm-environment/src/environment.rs] [Function: Environment::new()] [Default gas parameter abuse] When gas parameters fail to load and zeros are used, can an attacker execute resource-intensive native functions (cryptographic operations, complex math) for free, causing DoS through computational exhaustion?
